entry.title: HTML-6: Managing Footer
entry.content:
Footer is the end of your page, in footer there are two article tags, footer-left and footer-right, both of them are to come side by side. footer-left will cover 30% of screen, footer-right will cover around 60% of screen, 1% will be given to margin and remaining screen will be flexible.

Output:

Footer contains should be changed, you can check out better footer modles on google, and check out what you want to write. Codes, favicons should be better than other for footer.

entry.title: HTML-4:Making Header
entry.content:
In the header we have made contains two navs navleft and navright. navleft will contain the heading of blog, while navright will contain the menu of the blog. Now letâ€™s continue editing the previous blog

HTML

Output:


My Blog
  • Home
  • About
  • Contact
  • Write for us


    • Now letâ€™s style our navbar
    Make main.css

    Output:

    My Blog
  • Home
  • About
  • Contact
  • Write for us

    • If you like you can also add fancy things like fa fa-icons, or change the font

entry.title: C tutorial-4:Algebra
entry.content:
Now letâ€™s begin again. Now we are going to look towards algerbra like +,-,*,/. To start with lets initialize two variables â€˜aâ€™ and â€˜bâ€™

Or we can also use float

The only problem that I feel from float is that it gives .00 even for normal integers.
Now lets ask user for the value of â€˜aâ€™ and â€˜bâ€™

Now let us initialize outputs

Lets start Processing

Now let us print the outputs

Lets see what do we get as a output considering inputs as a=20 and b=40

20
40
#=>For int
60
-20
800
0
#=>For float
60.00
-20.00
800.00
0.50

Some compiler might give garbage value to subs and div while using int
Unlike our normal airthemetics there is a sign % used for arithmetic in C programming, letâ€™s see what it does

Letâ€™s see its output
Output:

1

Now how does this one come and what does % do?. Letâ€™s see if we divide 10 by 3 then 3*3=9 with remainder 1. This is what % does, it finds our remainder when a number is divided by another number.

entry.title: C tutorial-3:Print variable
entry.content:
Do you remember using printf variable and scanf variable. If you do thatâ€™s what we need now.

If you remember the initialiser for int is %d, char is %c and float is %d to print,

here we do not need & infront of variable because & is used only while a value is to be stored from user i.e during scanf
Output:

10 a 1.213

Now if you want them to print in different lines you can always use /n

Now the output will be
Output:

10
a
1.213

You can also write printf itself on different lines but it will be of no work until you give \n on each printf

The output will have no change
Output:

10
a
1.213

entry.title: HTML-2:Making body
entry.content:
To start with, maaking a HTML-5 webpage we have to strat from the first tag. Then the links, meta tags, the head, then the body.

HTML

entry.title: C tutorial-2:Variables and Scanf
entry.content:
You would certainy not only always print Hello World! in your C program But it is almost all about print and scan, thatâ€™s what the user sees. To begin with scanning from user. We need to understand how to declare a variable, initialise it or give value to it. Now letâ€™s begin

Now what is int, char and float?

int is used for giving integer value to a variable, i.e in above program, you can give any integer value to a, i.e 1, 2 , 100, 23213,â€¦.. but you can not give any character value like â€˜aâ€™, â€˜câ€™,â€¦ or any numeric value with decimals like 1.223, 123.213
char is used for giving any character value to a variable. i.e in above program you can give any single character value to b. like 1,2,3,â€¦.9 or â€˜aâ€™,â€™bâ€™,â€™câ€™â€¦â€¦.â€™zâ€™ but not more than one charactr like â€˜bibekâ€™ or â€˜blogâ€™ or even â€˜isâ€™.
float is used for giving numeric value with decimals to a variable. i.e in above program you can give any numeric value to c, like 1 2 23 4324.432 â€¦.. but float does not take alphabetical or unique characters.
Now lets give some value to our variables. Now there are three methods of giving value to a variable.

1. Initialise

2.Define and Declare

User defined

To understand how to give value to variable by user, we have to know about scanf() function.

here %d is for saying compiler that it is a integer. after â€œ â€œ there is ,&a, this is for saying compiler where to save the value given by user
%c is for char
%f is for float

Variable type Initialiser Â  Bytes
Integer %d Â  2 or 4bytes
Character %c Â  1byte
Float %f Â  4 or 8 bytes
Long integer %ld Â  double of integer
String %s Â  defined during declaration

entry.title: Html-1:Starting Html5
entry.content:
If you have ever used HTML in your life, HTML5 is easy and even if you have not, HTML5 is nothing but HTML with more keywords. So you can learn HTML5 at once. HTML or Hyper Text Markup Language is a Markup Language as seen in its name.It is like a skeleton of a body.

The above tag is 1st tag of HTML5, the tag tells browser that the file reading should be in HTML5.

Head contains links, scripts, meta-tags, title, favicons. Then comes the body tag

Body is the place where all your file is made, like divisions, headers, text,navs,all.

Divisions of body

1. Header

2. Section

3. Footer

Do you remember using of <div> tags in website while making it in html, bootstrap. The change in HTML5 is change of <div class='header'> to <header class='header'>, some people ask why there is need of HTML5 when we have been using div already. The need is during editing. HTML5 is easier to edit comparing with other versions of HTML.
=>Using older versions of HTML

=>Using HTML5

You can see the simple part of body looks much easier in HTML5 than HTML itself, the HTML gets much messy conpared to HTML5 when a complete webpage is build.

entry.title: C tutorial-1:Printf
entry.content:
The first thnig that anyone will learn on Btech CSE is C programming. To start what is c programming. It is just a subject oriented language. Anyone would wonder why do we need C language when we already have object oriented programming languages like c++. But in reality we do need C programming language because each and every language that comes futher is further extention of C language.(Atleast thatâ€™s what our teacher said to make us believe that C is important). Now what do we need to start learning C programming. We need an operating system. any operating system. Windows or Linux or Mac or any other. And you will need an editing software. Like while I was using windows, I used Dev C++, some of my friends used Code Blocks.You can visit their official website, download and install. Easy as that. For linux you can use any editor just like gedit, or leafpad, I personally like to use Atom. to download atom just go to Atom website and download it and install it using your terminal. I have never used mac so Iâ€™ve no idea what works for mac, but you can always google. Now what would be the first thing to do in C programming. Like every other tutorial you might have read or watched, Iâ€™m also going to print hello world. You have to keep in mind about the header, #include<stdio.h>is the header file of all C programs The content is written in int main() or main() or void main() depending upon compiler. All content are written inside curly brackets of int main(){}

printf is a keyword, I called it print function just to remember, The thing you have to remember is that C programming is case sensitive unlike html, almost all keywords are in lowecase. so Printf and printf are completely different in terms of C programming.The above code will give the below output.
Output:

Hello World!

Now what you have to understand is except for % and / annything that you will write between â€œ and â€œ of your printf will be printed as such in your output. Now the question that I forgot to tell is how to get the output. To get the output in Devc++ or other windows software, You can click compile and run in tab compile for linux to get output you have to open terminal in same file location where your program is saved and type following.

Now letâ€™s see what happens when we use keyword printf two times in a row.

Output:

Hello World!Hello World!

The output is not what you expected, or is it? We expected two Hello World!s to come in two different lines but what we forgot is to tell the compiler to break line just like <br> that we use to break line in html, in C we have /n now where to keep it in printf

Now do you remember that except for % and / elements everything except for it gets printed as it is. So the output will be
Output:

Hello World!
Hello World!

For linux I recommend to use /n on both printf statements to get the terminal initials a line below when our program ends.
